awd_titl_txt: Geometry and Topology of Holomorphic Symplectic Varieties
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic geometry is a subject studying algebraic varieties, which are spaces described by solutions of polynomial equations. This subject started with the work of the ancient Greeks about ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas, and now it has grown to be a modern subject sharing many rich connections with physics and computer science. The research supported by this NSF award will focus on an important class of algebraic varieties, called the holomorphic symplectic varieties, that lie at the crossroads of geometry, representation theory, and mathematical physics. A better understanding of these varieties will bring deep insights in both algebraic geometry and its related fields.

In this project, the PI will build connections between compact and noncompact holomorphic symplectic varieties with a focus on the P=W conjecture, which is a central conjecture connecting Hitchin's integrable systems and Hodge theory. Compact holomorphic symplectic varieties, which are higher dimensional generalizations of K3 surfaces, have been studied intensively for decades. A systematic way to compare compact and noncompact geometries, and to introduce new techniques to Hitchin systems from compact holomorphic symplectic varieties will bring fresh perspectives and fruitful outcomes to the P=W conjecture and related questions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The awarded project built links between two different areas. One is algebraic geometry, which is a subject with a very long history studying zeros of polynomail equations. The other is the study of holomorphic symplectic geometries, which is a modern subject focusing on certain spaces lying in the crossroads of complex geometry, representation theory, mathematical physics, and topology. The objects involved include moduli of Higgs bundles, character varieties, K3 surfaces and their higher dimensional analogs.

Mathematically, the P.I. resolved several conjectures in these areas by building and combining tools from different roots. During the period of this award, more than 10 research articles were written by the P.I., most of which had already been published or accepted in top mathematical research journals. The mathematical progress of the P.I. includes a proof of the P=W conjecture for non-abelian Hodge theory, a proof of the Hausel-Thaddeus conjecture for mirror symmetry of Hitchin systems, and building connections between Hodge modules and Lagrangian fibrations. The solutions to these conjetures and the discorveries of these phenomena deepen our understanding and widen our knowledge in the subject of holomorphic symplectic geometry. Moreover, the tools built by the P.I. and his collaborators may have further impact on applications to nearby areas.

Within the mathematical community and educational activities, the P.I. actively advises and mentors students and young researchers. The P.I. delivered lectures in seminars, workshops, conferences, and summer schools explaining his directions. This aids in rendering the technical aspects of his area more accessible to beginners. Furthermore, in the development of this project, the P.I. put effort on finding good problems for young researchers. Working on these problems helped students to gain experience, learn relevant techniques, and finally grow to be independent and mature researchers.
